Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2013 12:41AM choochoobella wrote: Hi everyone.  This is my first post.  I've actually wanted to post on other topics, but sometimes I feel a little funny jumping in as a newcomer.  Thank God for all of you very well-informed and helpful women.  I am so comforted by your knowledge and presence.  I am an example of someone who was given the option of a lumpectomy or mastectomy for my cancer.  The mammogram picked up on one tumor that appeared to be about 1.6cm based on the follow-up ultrasound-guided biopsy.  I have invasive lobular carcinoma.  My breast cancer surgeon was a bit wary of doing only the lumpectomy due to the difficulty of picking up lobular tumors during exams or via imaging.  My tumor was difficult to feel, just felt like a bit of a thickening.  My surgeon also cited the fact that studies show that lobular cancer tends to arise in the other breast between 30% and 50% of the time, depending on which study you read.  I opted for a bilateral mastectomy.  The pathology report shows that I had five tumors, two in one breast and three in the other, in addition to a considerable amount of LCIS.  The tumor the mammogram picked up on was not my largest tumor.  As Colt45 said, there can be extenuating circumstances that make a person choose mastectomy over lumpectomy.  In my case, as the tumors turned out to be multi-focal, I'm grateful to have those babies gone!  As my cancer is highly estrogen/progesterone positive, I'll be having a hysterectomy on Monday, then I'll begin Femara.  Afraid, please don't waste time on the decision you made.  We all make the very best decisions we can with the information we have at the time.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2015 02:46AM - edited Sep 27, 2015 04:22AM by choochoobella I always "run hot." Even on cold nights, I usually don't like more than a sheet over me. When I wore mastectomy bras and inserted prosthetics, I was miserable during the warmer months. I would end up with a heat rash on my chest. Just a few months ago, I found these lightweight little bras that American Eagle sells that are 98% cotton. Since they are targeted to young girls, they have built-in padding that creates a nice little A cup for me. I'm happy to just have an indication of a bump even though my breasts used to be a C-cup. I barely perspire with these things on. They have softer elastic too, so they don't press on my scars. I paid $19.99 for each and bought nine of them. They're all I wear anymore. If it's a particularly scalding day, I put a little talcum powder on my chest before I put the bra on. This has been an awesome solution for me. I looked up the name of the bra on my order form and it is "Aerie Cotton Push-up Bralette." If you type this in quotes on Google and hit images, the first couple of images are of the bra I got. Wouldn't you know it though? It has now sold out. I don't know if they will be making this bra again. I hope so because my prosthetics have been in the drawer ever since I got these bras.
